Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A casual conversation drifts toward personal topics but nothing particularly sensitive is mentioned.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from Jamie, my closest friend. I could tell right away from her reply that she’d misunderstood my last text—she sounded hurt, and I knew I needed to call her immediately to clear things up. That’s what friends do: we talk things out, we don’t let misunderstandings fester. But at that exact moment, I was sitting in the community center, volunteering at the weekly support group. The conversation with the group had drifted into personal territory, nothing too sensitive, but I was always careful to respect everyone’s privacy. I couldn’t just step out and take a call, not when I was supposed to be present and trustworthy. Yet, the longer I waited, the more I worried Jamie would think I was ignoring her or didn’t care. My mind raced, torn between the urge to be a good friend and the responsibility to honor the trust of those I was helping. I stared at my phone, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which expectation I should meet first.
